abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and institutional development impacts
            substantial. Key lessons stress the need for high level
            government commitments towards both technical progress, and
            resource mobilization and allocation, to be facilitated
            through project design, and management arrangements. Such
            facilitation should also prod the integration of project
            activities into the routine work programs of local
            governments, essential in achieving the impact, and
            sustainability of project achievements. However,
            projects' fund transfers should be used as incentives
            for structural reform in health services, and gains in line
            with national policy, and local needs, rather than
            prioritizing on health infrastructure investments as many
            local governments do, hampering the importance of system
            reform, capacity building, and service quality, and
            affordability. Moreover, the constraints of human resources
            in rural health reform remain critical, thus a focused
            sector work for human resources development is needed,
            including an adjustment of the roles of public, and private
            sector. Further improvements are needed in the areas of
            project financing; policy and planning as part of project
            design; and, in the uses of technical assistance,
            procurement of equipment, and, in balancing population
            coverage with supervisory support.
